newsitem.title: FRANCE: Suitors line up for GAN after EU aid approval.
newsitem.headline: Suitors line up for GAN after EU aid approval.

text.p: French state insurer GAN has a handful of potential buyers following European Commission approval on Wednesday of a 20-billion-franc government rescue package in return for a pledge to privatise the firm.

The company, which ran up losses of 35 billion francs ($5.6 billion) between 1992 and 1996 in the wake of a property market collapse in the late 1980s, is being eyed by French insurer AGF and a string of foreign companies.

Eureko, an Amsterdam-based alliance of six European financial services companies with no French presence, emerged last week as the latest suitor, saying it wanted to take over all of GAN and a maximum 25 percent of CIC, a profitable regional banking network.

Germany's Allianz AG, Fortis AG, Assicurazioni Generali SpA of Italy and ING Groep of the Netherlands have either expressed interest in acquiring GAN or are likely candidates, GAN chairman Didier Pfieffer has said.
French mutual insurer MAAF has also said it would like to buy GAN in collaboration with others.

The French government aid package approved by the European Commission in Brussels includes a capital injection of 11 billion francs along with a further nine billion to cover property divestment losses.
Of the 11 billion francs, some 3.9 billion has been earmarked for GAN Assurances and the other 7.1 billion for the property subsidiary UIC, which has already been put up for sale.

Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's team has agreed to honour the salvage plan drawn up by the previous centre-right government, which includes a commitment to privatise GAN and its banking subsidiary CIC.
Insurance analysts at Salomon Brothers in London recently valued GAN at 8.5 billion francs, saying AGF could afford to buy its fellow insurer without needing to raise fresh funds.
AGF had no official comment to make on Wednesday as the state rescue plan got the EU go-ahead.

But the firm has said in the past that it is interested in GAN depending on the price and, possibly taking a stake of 20 or 30 percent in banking subsidiary Credit Industriel et Commercial (CIC), which has ties with its parent in life assurance sales.
-- Brian Love, Paris Newsroom +33 1 4221 5452 ($ = 6.196 French Francs)
